      (a) Markham, A. Brigatinib: First Global Approval. Drugs 2017, 77, 1131– 1135,  DOI: 10.1007/s40265-017-0776-3
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28a
      Brigatinib: First Global Approval
      Markham, Anthony
      Drugs (2017), 77 (10), 1131-1135CODEN: DRUGAY; ISSN:0012-6667. (Springer International Publishing AG)
      Brigatinib (ALUNBRIG) is a small mol. antineoplastic anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) inhibitor being developed by ARIAD Pharmaceuticals (a wholly-owned subsidiary of Takeda Pharmaceutical Company). In Apr. 2017 brigatinib received accelerated approval in the USA for the treatment of patients with ALK-pos. metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have progressed on or are intolerant to crizotinib. The development of resistance to crizotinib is a therapeutic challenge that has led to the development of second-generation ALK-inhibitors such as brigatinib, which have activity against treatment-resistant ALK mutants. This article summarizes the milestones in the development of brigatinib leading to this first global approval for the treatment of patients with ALK-pos. metastatic NSCLC who have progressed on or are intolerant to crizotinib.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVOjsrzL&md5=c03f9d61e8e8fd4187d47ee207452f31
      .
      (b) Huang, W.-S.; Liu, S.; Zou, D.; Thomas, M.; Wang, Y.; Zhou, T.; Romero, J.; Kohlmann, A.; Li, F.; Qi, J.; Cai, L.; Dwight, T. A.; Xu, Y.; Xu, R.; Dodd, R.; Toms, A.; Parillon, L.; Lu, X.; Anjum, R.; Zhang, S.; Wang, F.; Keats, J.; Wardwell, S. D.; Ning, Y.; Xu, Q.; Moran, L. E.; Mohemmad, Q. K.; Jang, H. G.; Clackson, T.; Narasimhan, N. I.; Rivera, V. M.; Zhu, X.; Dalgarno, D.; Shakespeare, W. C. Discovery of Brigatinib (AP26113), a Phosphine Oxide-Containing, Potent, Orally Active Inhibitor of Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase. J. Med. Chem. 2016, 59, 4948– 4964,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b00306
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28b
      Discovery of Brigatinib (AP26113), a Phosphine Oxide-Containing, Potent, Orally Active Inhibitor of Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase
      Huang, Wei-Sheng; Liu, Shuangying; Zou, Dong; Thomas, Mathew; Wang, Yihan; Zhou, Tianjun; Romero, Jan; Kohlmann, Anna; Li, Feng; Qi, Jiwei; Cai, Lisi; Dwight, Timothy A.; Xu, Yongjin; Xu, Rongsong; Dodd, Rory; Toms, Angela; Parillon, Lois; Lu, Xiaohui; Anjum, Rana; Zhang, Sen; Wang, Frank; Keats, Jeffrey; Wardwell, Scott D.; Ning, Yaoyu; Xu, Qihong; Moran, Lauren E.; Mohemmad, Qurish K.; Jang, Hyun Gyung; Clackson, Tim; Narasimhan, Narayana I.; Rivera, Victor M.; Zhu, Xiaotian; Dalgarno, David; Shakespeare, William C.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2016), 59 (10), 4948-4964CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      In the treatment of echinoderm microtubule-assocd. protein-like 4 (EML4)-anaplastic lymphoma kinase pos. (ALK+) non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), secondary mutations within the ALK kinase domain have emerged as a major resistance mechanism to both first- and second-generation ALK inhibitors. This report describes the design and synthesis of a series of 2,4-diarylaminopyrimidine-based potent and selective ALK inhibitors culminating in identification of the investigational clin. candidate brigatinib. A unique structural feature of brigatinib is a phosphine oxide, an overlooked but novel hydrogen-bond acceptor that drives potency and selectivity in addn. to favorable ADME properties. Brigatinib displayed low nanomolar IC50s against native ALK and all tested clin. relevant ALK mutants in both enzyme-based biochem. and cell-based viability assays and demonstrated efficacy in multiple ALK+ xenografts in mice, including Karpas-299 (anaplastic large-cell lymphomas [ALCL]) and H3122 (NSCLC). Brigatinib represents the most clin. advanced phosphine oxide-contg. drug candidate to date and is currently being evaluated in a global phase 2 registration trial.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XntlCgur8%253D&md5=4cb93ff587579c97fda8aff0c7d43317

      Laurence, C.; Brameld, K. A.; Graton, J.; Le Questel, J.-Y.; Renault, E. The pKBHX Database: Toward a Better Understanding of Hydrogen-Bond Basicity for Medicinal Chemists. J. Med. Chem. 2009, 52, 4073– 4086,  DOI: 10.1021/jm801331y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      The pKBHX Database: Toward a Better Understanding of Hydrogen-Bond Basicity for Medicinal Chemists
      Laurence, Christian; Brameld, Ken A.; Graton, Jerome; Le Questel, Jean-Yves; Renault, Eric
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 52 (14), 4073-4086CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The pKBHX database is presented, which corresponds to three main fields of data: hydrogen bond donor identification, thermodn. data and spectroscopic data. The pKBHX scale of hydrogen donor basicity differs considerable from the pKBH+ scale of proton transfer basicity. The hydrogen bond basicities of functional groups relevant to medicinal chem. and drug design is reviewed.

      30a
      Discovery of novel phosphorus-containing steroids as selective glucocorticoid receptor antagonist
      Jiang, Weiqin; Fiordeliso, James J.; Allan, George; Linton, Olivia; Tannenbaum, Pamela; Xu, Jun; Zhu, Peifang; Gunnet, Joseph; Demarest, Keith; Lundeen, Scott; Sui, Zhihua
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2007), 17 (5), 1471-1474CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Mifepristone is a non-selective antagonist of 3-oxosteroid receptors with both abortifacient and anti-diabetic activities. For glucocorticoid receptor (GR) program, we sought an unexplored, synthetically accessible phosphorus-contg. steroidal mimetic of mifepristone, suitable for parallel synthesis of analogs. One compd., I, with high oral bioavailability (59%) in rat, exhibited functional antagonism of GR in oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Thus this series of compds. might be potentially useful for the treatment of type II diabetes.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhvVyjtb4%253D&md5=410209a3dd291517b395ade3fcb97815

      (b) Jang, J.; Son, J. B.; To, C.; Bahcall, M.; Kim, S. Y.; Kang, S. Y.; Mushajiang, M.; Lee, Y.; Jänne, P. A.; Choi, H. G.; Gray, N. S. Discovery of a Potent Dual ALK and EGFR T790M Inhibitor. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 136, 497– 510,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2017.04.079
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30b
      Discovery of a potent dual ALK and EGFR T790M inhibitor
      Jang, Jaebong; Son, Jung Beom; To, Ciric; Bahcall, Magda; Kim, So Young; Kang, Seock Yong; Mushajiang, Mierzhati; Lee, Younho; Janne, Pasi A.; Choi, Hwan Geun; Gray, Nathanael S.
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 136 (), 497-510CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      The mutational activations of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) are validated oncogenic events and the targets of approved drugs to treat non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Here we report highly potent dual small mol. inhibitors of both ALK and EGFR, particularly the T790M mutant which confers resistance to first generation EGFR inhibitors. Dual ALK/EGFR inhibitors may provide an efficient approach to prevent resistance that arises as a consequence of clin. reported reciprocal activation mechanisms. Our lead compd. 7c displayed remarkable inhibitory activities against both ALK and EGFR in enzymic and cellular assays. We demonstrate that 7c is capable of recapitulating the signaling effects and antiproliferative activity of combined treatment with the approved ALK inhibitor ceritinib and T790M EGFR inhibitor osimertinib against patient-derived non-small cell lung cancer cell line, DFCI032 which harbors both EML4-ALK and activated EGFR.

      (d) Oliyai, R.; Shaw, J.-P.; Sueoka-Lennen, C. M.; Cundy, K. C.; Arimilli, M. N.; Jones, R. J.; Lee, W. A. Aryl Ester Prodrugs of Cyclic HPMPC. I: Physicochemical Characterization and In Vitro Biological Stability. Pharm. Res. 1999, 16, 1687– 1693,  DOI: 10.1023/A:1018945713623
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30d
      Aryl ester prodrugs of cyclic HPMPC. I: physicochemical characterization and in vitro biological stability
      Oliyai, Reza; Shaw, Jeng-Pyng; Sueoka-Lennen, Cathy M.; Cundy, Kenneth C.; Arimilli, Murty N.; Jones, Robert J.; Lee, William A.
      Pharmaceutical Research (1999), 16 (11), 1687-1693CODEN: PHREEB; ISSN:0724-8741. (Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers)
      The chem., enzymic, and biol. stabilities and phys. properties of a series of salicylate and aryl ester prodrugs of the antiviral agent, cyclic HPMPC (cidofovir), were evaluated to support the selection of a lead compd. for clin. development. Chem. degrdn. of the prodrugs resulted in the formation of both cyclic HPMPC and the corresponding HPMPC monoester. Chem. stability was dependent on the orientation of the exo-cyclic ligand; the equatorial isomers were 5.4- to 9.4-fold more reactive than the axial isomers. In the presence of PLCE, the salicylate prodrugs cleaved exclusively to give cyclic HPMPC and not the HPMPC monoester. In plasma, but not intestinal or liver homogenates, the salicylate esters of cyclic HPMPC cleaved readily with a rate dependent on the chain length of the alkyl ester substituent. The carboxylate function on the salicylate prodrugs of cyclic HPMPC provides an addnl. handle to chem. modify the lipophilicity, soly. and the biol. reactivity of the prodrug. In tissue and enzymic studies, the major degrdn. product is cyclic HPMPC. The salicylate ester prodrugs are attractive drug candidates for further in vivo evaluation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnt1Ggs7s%253D&md5=9e360a98bb5fd2ee221cee7068a982a9

      Frings, M.; Bolm, C.; Blum, A.; Gnamm, C. Sulfoximines from a Medicinal Chemist’s Perspective: Physicochemical and in vitro Parameters Relevant for Drug Discovery. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 126, 225– 245,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2016.09.091
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31
      Sulfoximines from a Medicinal Chemist's Perspective: Physicochemical and in vitro Parameters Relevant for Drug Discovery
      Frings, Marcus; Bolm, Carsten; Blum, Andreas; Gnamm, Christian
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 126 (), 225-245CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      Sulfoximines, sulfondiimides and sulfonimidamides are fascinating but not yet fully explored variants of the common sulfone or sulfonamide motif. In this study, we report the physicochem. and in vitro properties of sulfoximines and compare them with related analogs and isosteres. Furthermore, we present a matched mol. pair anal. of compds. from drug discovery projects within Boehringer Ingelheim. We demonstrate that the sulfoximine moiety is a chem. stable, comparatively polar and weakly basic functional group, often leading to favorable aq. soly., permeability and metabolic stability. Moreover, their addnl. vectors at nitrogen enable simple chem. modifications and thus facilitate exploration and fine-tuning of the mol. properties. We conclude that sulfoximines and their congeners do not exhibit any intrinsic flaw but significantly enrich the toolbox of medicinal chemists.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVahsbfK&md5=8a7939f22425f46ad9eb87fcddd29099
    32. 32
      (a) Deininger, M.; Buchdunger, E.; Druker, B. J. The Development of Imatinib as a Therapeutic Agent for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia. Blood 2005, 105, 2640– 2653,  DOI: 10.1182/blood-2004-08-3097
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32a
      The development of imatinib as a therapeutic agent for chronic myeloid leukemia
      Deininger, Michael; Buchdunger, Elisabeth; Druker, Brian J.
      Blood (2005), 105 (7), 2640-2653CODEN: BLOOAW; ISSN:0006-4971. (American Society of Hematology)
      A review. Imatinib has revolutionized drug therapy of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Preclin. studies were promising but the results of clin. trials by far exceeded expectations. Responses in chronic phase are unprecedented, with rates of complete cytogenetic response (CCR) of more than 40% in patients after failure of interferon-α (IFN) and more than 80% in newly diagnosed patients, a level of efficacy that led to regulatory approval in record time. While most of these responses are stable, resistance to treatment after an initial response is common in more advanced phases of the disease. Mutations in the kinase domain (KD) of BCR-ABL that impair imatinib binding have been identified as the leading cause of resistance. Patients with CCR who achieve a profound redn. of BCR-ABL mRNA have a very low risk of disease progression. However, residual disease usually remains detectable with reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), indicating that disease eradication may pose a significant challenge. The mechanisms underlying the persistence of minimal residual disease are unknown. In this manuscript, we review the preclin. and clin. development of imatinib for the therapy of CML, resistance and strategies that may help to eliminate resistant or residual leukemia.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXivFGmsb0%253D&md5=894d4159f7a65f3ae5304249d6ba1e75
      .
      (b) Capdeville, R.; Buchdunger, E.; Zimmermann, J.; Matter, A. Glivec (STI571, imatinib), a Rationally Developed, Targeted Anticancer Drug. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2002, 1, 493– 502,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd839
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32b
      Glivec (STI571, imatinib), a rationally developed, targeted anticancer drug
      Capdeville, Renaud; Buchdunger, Elisabeth; Zimmermann, Juerg; Matter, Alex
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2002), 1 (7), 493-502CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. In the early 1980s, it became apparent that the work of pioneers such as Robert Weinberg, Mariano Barbacid and many others in identifying cancer-causing genes in humans was opening the door to a new era in anticancer research. Motivated by this, and by dissatisfaction with the limited efficacy and tolerability of available anticancer modalities, a drug discovery program was initiated with the aim of rationally developing targeted anticancer therapies. Here, we describe how this program led to the discovery and continuing development of Glivec (Gleevec in the United States), the first selective tyrosine-kinase inhibitor to be approved for the treatment of a cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XkvFKlurY%253D&md5=c8f6b7a66f74b64f0dedb5e641097acc
      .
      (c) Lin, Y.-L.; Meng, Y.; Jiang, W.; Roux, B. Explaining why Gleevec is a Specific and Potent Inhibitor of Abl Kinase. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2013, 110, 1664– 1669,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1214330110
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32c
      Explaining why Gleevec is a specific and potent inhibitor of Abl kinase
      Lin, Yen-Lin; Meng, Yilin; Jiang, Wei; Roux, Benoit
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2013), 110 (5), 1664-1669, S1664/1-S1664/10CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Tyrosine kinases present attractive drug targets for specific types of cancers. Gleevec, a well-known therapeutic agent against chronic myelogenous leukemia, is an effective inhibitor of Abl tyrosine kinase. However, Gleevec fails to inhibit closely homologous tyrosine kinases, such as c-Src. Because many structural features of the binding site are conserved, the mol. determinants responsible for binding specificity are not immediately apparent. Some have attributed the difference in binding specificity of Gleevec to subtle variations in ligand-protein interactions (binding affinity control), whereas others have proposed that it is the conformation of the DFG motif, in which ligand binding is only accessible to Abl and not to c-Src (conformational selection control). To address this issue, the abs. binding free energy was computed using all-atom mol. dynamics simulations with explicit solvent. The results of the free energy simulations are in good agreement with expts., thereby enabling a meaningful decompn. of the binding free energy to elucidate the factors controlling Gleevec's binding specificity. The latter is shown to be controlled by a conformational selection mechanism and also by differences in key van der Waals interactions responsible for the stabilization of Gleevec in the binding pocket of Abl.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXislChsrg%253D&md5=927c13dba7770e5e306a6e8d6322dc8d
      .
      (d) Sirvent, J. A.; Lücking, U. Novel Pieces for the Emerging Picture of Sulfoximines in Drug Discovery: Synthesis and Evaluation of Sulfoximine Analogues of Marketed Drugs and Advanced Clinical Candidates. ChemMedChem 2017, 12, 487– 501,  DOI: 10.1002/cmdc.201700044
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32d
      Novel Pieces for the Emerging Picture of Sulfoximines in Drug Discovery: Synthesis and Evaluation of Sulfoximine Analogues of Marketed Drugs and Advanced Clinical Candidates
      Sirvent, Juan Alberto; Luecking, Ulrich
      ChemMedChem (2017), 12 (7), 487-501CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Sulfoximines have gained considerable recognition as an important structural motif in drug discovery of late. In particular, the clin. kinase inhibitors for the treatment of cancer, roniciclib (pan-CDK inhibitor), BAY 1143572 (P-TEFb inhibitor), and AZD 6738 (ATR inhibitor), have recently drawn considerable attention. While the interest in this underrepresented functional group in drug discovery is clearly on the rise, there remains an incomplete understanding of the medicinal-chem.-relevant properties of sulfoximines. Herein we report the synthesis and in vitro characterization of a variety of sulfoximine analogs of marketed drugs and advanced clin. candidates to gain a better understanding of this neglected functional group and its potential in drug discovery.

      34b
      Palladium-Catalyzed Direct Decarbonylative Phosphorylation of Benzoic Acids with P(O)-H Compounds
      Zhang, Ji-Shu; Chen, Tieqiao; Han, Li-Biao
      European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2020), 2020 (9), 1148-1153CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A direct decarbonylative phosphorylation of benzoic acids catalyzed by palladium was disclosed. Under the reaction conditions, a wide range of benzoic acids coupled readily with all the three kinds of P(O)-H compds., i.e. secondary phosphine oxides, H-phosphinates and H-phosphonates, producing the corresponding organophosphorus compds. in good to high yields. This reaction could be conducted at a gram scale and applied in the late-stage phosphorylative modification of carboxylic acids drug mols. These results well demonstrated the potential synthetic value of this new reaction in org. synthesis.

      34c
      Cobalt catalyzed C-P bond formation by cross-coupling of boronic acids with P(O)H compounds in presence of zinc
      Hicks, Ian; McTague, Jonathan; Hapatsha, Tatiana; Teriak, Rania; Kaur, Parminder
      Molecules (2020), 25 (2), 290CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
      In our current work, we have reported the first cobalt-catalyzed cross-coupling of arylboronic acid with alkyl/aryl phosphites under mild conditions. The reaction was carried out in the presence of zinc powder as an additive and ter-pyridine as a ligand. The use of non-precious cobalt salt makes the protocol advantageous, as it is inexpensive and more abundant than the previously used methods where precious metal salts (Pd and Pt) were used. The reaction has a wide substrate scope and the products were obtained in good yields.

      An efficient nickel-catalyzed phosphorylation of phenol derivs. with P(O)-H compds. via C-O/P-H cross-coupling is described. Under the reaction conditions, various Ph pivalates coupled readily with hydrogen phosphoryl compds. to afford the corresponding coupling products aryl phosphonates and aryl phosphine oxides in good to high yields.

      Nickel-Catalyzed C-P Cross-Coupling of Arylboronic Acids with P(O)H Compounds
      Hu, Gaobo; Chen, Weizhu; Fu, Tingting; Peng, Zhimin; Qiao, Hongwei; Gao, Yuxing; Zhao, Yufen
      Organic Letters (2013), 15 (20), 5362-5365CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      A novel and efficient Ni-catalyzed coupling of a wide range of arylboronic acids with H-phosphites, H-phosphinate esters, and H-phosphine oxides has been developed, providing a general and powerful tool for the synthesis of various aryl-phosphorus compds., esp. for valuable triarylphosphine oxides, in good to excellent yield. This protocol is the first Ni-catalyzed C-P bond-forming reaction between arylboronic acids and P(O)H compds.

      35c
      Room Temperature, Palladium-Mediated P-Arylation of Secondary Phosphine Oxides
      Bloomfield, Aaron J.; Herzon, Seth B.
      Organic Letters (2012), 14 (17), 4370-4373CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      We show that a broad range of aryl iodides are efficiently coupled with secondary phosphine oxides using 1 mol % of a catalyst formed in situ from tris(dibenzylideneacetone)dipalladium and Xantphos. Scalemic (S)-methylphenylphosphine oxide is shown to undergo arylation without detectable stereoerosion. The application of this method to the synthesis of novel P-chiral phosphines and PCP ligands is demonstrated.

      Efficient copper(I)-catalyzed coupling of secondary phosphine oxides with aryl halides
      Stankevic, Marek; Wlodarczyk, Adam
      Tetrahedron (2013), 69 (1), 73-81CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A catalytic system has been developed for the efficient synthesis of tertiary arylphosphine oxides by coupling of readily available secondary phosphine oxides with aryl bromides or iodides in the presence of copper(I) iodide as a catalyst and (S)-α-phenylethylamine as a ligand. The system exhibits high activity in the coupling of secondary diaryl-, alkylaryl- and dialkylphosphine oxides.

      36a
      Enantiomerically pure 1,2,5-triphenylphospholane through the synthesis and resolution of the chiral trans-(2,5)-diphenylphospholanic acid
      Guillen, Frederic; Fiaud, Jean-Claude
      Tetrahedron Letters (1999), 40 (15), 2939-2942CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      The asym. synthesis and resoln. of trans-(2,5)-diphenylphospholanic acid I beginning with the cyclocondensation of Cl2P(NMe2) with 1,4-diphenylbuta-1,3-diene is described. The phosphinic acid I was converted into optically active (1,2,5)-triphenylphospholane II which was used as a chiral ligand in Rh-catalyzed hydrogenation of N-acetyl dehydrophenylalanine Me ester to give quant. yield of Me N-acetylphenylalaninate with 82% e.e.

    38. 38
      Kendall, A. J.; Salazar, C. A.; Martino, P. F.; Tyler, D. R. Direct Conversion of Phosphonates to Phosphine Oxides: An Improved Synthetic Route to Phosphines Including the First Synthesis of Methyl JohnPhos. Organometallics 2014, 33, 6171– 6178,  DOI: 10.1021/om500854u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      38
      Direct Conversion of Phosphonates to Phosphine Oxides: An Improved Synthetic Route to Phosphines Including the First Synthesis of Methyl JohnPhos
      Kendall, Alexander J.; Salazar, Chase A.; Martino, Patrick F.; Tyler, David R.
      Organometallics (2014), 33 (21), 6171-6178CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
      The synthesis of tertiary phosphine oxides from phosphonates was achieved reliably and in good to excellent yields using stoichiometric amts. of alkyl or aryl Grignard reagents and sodium trifluoromethanesulfonate (NaOTf). In the absence of the NaOTf additive, covalent coordination oligomers of magnesium and phosphorus species dominate the reaction, producing very low yields of phosphine oxide, but high conversions of the phosphonate starting material. Mechanistic studies revealed that a five-coordinate phosphorus species-not a phosphinate-is the reaction intermediate. A diverse array of phosphonates was converted to phosphine oxides using a variety of Grignard reagents for direct carbon-phosphorus functionalization. This new methodol. esp. simplifies the synthesis of dimethylphosphino (RPMe2)-type phosphines by using air-, water-, and silica-stable intermediates. To highlight this reaction, a new Buchwald-type ligand ([1,1'-biphenyl]-2-yldimethylphosphine, or Me JohnPhos) and a classic bidentate phosphine, bis(diphenylphosphino)propane (dppp), were synthesized in excellent yields.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslylt7zF&md5=5bad9bcdce81c76f369a34f1e6a629db
    39. 39
      (a) Gray, M.; Chapell, B. J.; Felding, J.; Taylor, N. J.; Snieckus, V. The Di-t-Butylphosphinyl Directed ortho Metalation Group. Synthesis of Hindered Dialkylarylphosphines. Synlett 1998, 1998, 422– 424,  DOI: 10.1055/s-1998-1655
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      (b) Schreiter, W. J.; Monteil, A. R.; Kalachnikova, E.; Peterson, M. A.; Moulis, M. D.; Gasery, C. D.; McCandless, G. T.; Fronczek, F. R.; Stanley, G. G.       [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      39b
      Synthesis and Characterization of a New Binucleating Tetraphosphine Ligand Based on 1,2-Phenylene Chelates and the Structures of Dinickel Tetrachloride Complexes of the Ligand
      Schreiter, William J.; Monteil, Alexandre R.; Kalachnikova, Ekaterina; Peterson, Marc A.; Moulis, Marshall D.; Gasery, Ciera D.; McCandless, Gregory T.; Fronczek, Frank R.; Stanley, George G.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (19), 10036-10038CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A new binucleating tetraphosphine ligand, rac- and meso-(Et2P-1,2-C6H4)P(Ph)CH2(Ph)P(1,2-C6H4PEt2) (et,ph-P4-Ph), was synthesized. Sepn. and purifn. of the ligand diastereomers were accomplished via column chromatog. Ni2Cl4(et,ph-P4-Ph) complexes of both diastereomers were prepd. in high yield and crystallog. characterized.

      (a) Heuschmann, M.; Quast, H. Dreigliedrige Heterocyclen, 14. α-Halogenierung von Tertiären Phosphanoxiden. Chem. Ber. 1982, 115, 3384– 3401,  DOI: 10.1002/cber.19821151015
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      40a
      Three-membered-ring heterocycles. 14. α-Halogenation of tertiary phosphine oxides
      Heuschmann, Manfred; Quast, Helmut
      Chemische Berichte (1982), 115 (10), 3384-401CODEN: CHBEAM; ISSN:0009-2940.
      (RCH2)2P(O)R1 [R = R1 = CMe3 (I), Ph (II); R = CMe3, R1 = Ph (III); R = Ph, R1 = CMe3 (IV)] were prepd. from PhCH2P(O)Cl and R1MgX (X = halo) and from R1PCl2 and RCH2MgX. II reacted with Br to give all 3 possible diastereomeric α,α'-dibromophosphine oxides (R,R/S,S)-, r-, and s-(PhCHBr)2P(O)Ph, and PhCHBr(PhCH2)P(O)Ph. I, III, and IV were lithiated with BuLi to give the α,α'-dilithio phosphine oxides, which, with CCl4 below -80° gave RCH2(RCHCl)P(O)R1 [R = R1 = CMe3 (V) R = Ph, R1 = CMe3 (VI); R = CMe3, R1 = Ph), whose diastereomeric ratios were controlled kinetically. The thermodynamically controlled ratios were adjusted with bases. Whereas the α-lithiated I and IV gave V and VI, resp., with excess CCl4, PhCH2(PhCCl2)P(O)CMe3 was formed from PhCH2(PhCHLi)P(O)CMe3. This difference was attributed to the acidity of the α-protons and steric factors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3sXlsVShug%253D%253D&md5=4487fc8d432a7a28be5bacc118c9e92a
      .
      (b) Davies, W. C.; Pearse, P. L.; Jones, W. J. CLXIV.–Tertiary Phosphines Containing the Higher Alkyl Radicals. J. Chem. Soc. 1929, 0, 1262– 1268,  DOI: 10.1039/JR9290001262
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      40b
      Tertiary phosphines containing the higher alkyl radicals
      Davies, Walter C.; Pearse, Perov L.; Jones, Wm. Jacob
      Journal of the Chemical Society (1929), (), 1262-8CODEN: JCSOA9; ISSN:0368-1769.
      cf. Davies and Jones, C. A. 23, 2150. PCl3 (12 cc.) in 50 cc. Et2O, added to the Grignard reagent from 56 cc. PrBr, gives 10 g. tripropylphosphine, b50 103.5°, b760 187.5°, d420 0.807; CS2 compd., m. 108°; mercurichloride, m. 137°. Methyltripropylphosphonium iodide, m. 212.5°; tetrapropylphosphonium bromide, decomps. 200°. PhPCl2 (19 cc.) and the Grignard reagent from 36 cc. PrBr give 17 g. phenyldipropylphosphine, b19 159°, d425 0.925; mercurichloride, m. 192.5°; phenylmethyldipropylphosphonium iodide, m. 137°; phenyltripropylphosphonium bromide, m. 131.5°. p-MeC6H4PCl2 (20 cc.) and the Grignard reagent from 36 cc. PrBr give 14 g. p-tolyldipropylphosphine, b50 174°, d425 0.921; mercurichloride, m. 129.5°; p-tolylmethyldipropylphosphonium iodide, m. 81.5°; p-tolyltripropylphonium bromide, m. 125.5°, hygroscopic needles, formed with difficulty. PCl3 (14 cc.) and the Grignard reagent from 94 cc. iso-BuBr give 12 g. triisobutylphosphine, b50 126°; the CS2 compd. forms highly unstable red crystals; mercurichloride, m. 191.5°. PhPCl2 (11 cc.) and the Grignard reagent from 47 cc. iso-BuBr give 10 g. phenyldiisobutylphosphine, b30 168°, d425 0.910; mercurichloride, m. 158.5°; phenylmethyldiisobutylphosphonium iodide, m. 166.5°. p-MeC6H4PCl2 (15 cc.) and the Grignard reagent from 47 cc. iso-BuBr give 6 g. p-tolyldiisobutylphosphine, b50 182.5-4.5°, d425 0.915; the HgCl2 compd. could not be obtained pure; p-tolylmethyldiisobutylphosphonium iodide, an oil which crystallizes on long standing. PCl3 (10.5 cc.) and the Grignard reagent from 78 cc. AmBr give 9 g. triamylphosphine, b50 185.5°, d425 0.820; CS2 compd., m. 55°. Phenyldiamylphosphine, in 10 g. yield from 11.5 cc. PhPCl2 and the Grignard reagent from 42 cc. AmBr, b50 210°, d425 0.902, only partially miscible with abs. EtOH at 15°; mercurichloride, m. 108°; phenylmethyldiamylphosphonium iodide, m. 90.5°. p-Tolyldiamylphosphine, b50 220°, d425 0.898; 11 g. yield from 11 cc. p-MeC6H4PCl2, and the Grignard reagent from 51 cc. AmBr; this is less completely miscible with abs. EtOH than the Ph deriv.; mercurichloride, m. 112°; p-tolymethyldiamylphonium iodide, an oil which crystallizes or long standing. Tri-[dl-β-methylbutyl]phosphine, b10 113-7°; poor yield. Phenyldi-[dl-β-methylbutyl]phosphine, b50 198°, d425 0.906, in 8 g. yield from 14 cc. PhPCl2 and the Grignard reagent from 51 cc. of EtMeCHCH2Br; mercurichloride, m. 120°; phenylmethyldi-[di-β-methylbutyl]phosphonium iodide, m. 150°. p-Tolyldi[dl-β-methylbutyl]phosphine, b50 210-1°, d425 0.902, in 7 g. yield from 11 cc. p-MeC6H4PCl2; mercurichloride, m. 99°; p-tolylmethyldi-[dl-β-methylbutyl]phosphonium iodide, m. 131°. Trisoamylphosphine, b11 131°, results in 9 g. yield from 10.5 cc. PCl3 and the Grignard reagent from 78 cc. iso-AmBr, the reaction and purifn. being carried out in a CO2 atm.; CS2 compd., red, m. 79.5°; methyltriisoamylphosphonium iodide, an oil which solidifies on keeping. Phenyldiisoamylphosphine, b50 198.5°, d425 0.900, results in 10 g. yield from 14 cc. PhPCl2; mercurichloride, m. 152°; phenylmethyldiisoamylphosphonium iodide, m. 181.5°. p-Tolyidiisoamylphosphine, b50 210°, d425 0.894; mercurichloride, m. 107°; p-tolylmethyldiisoamylphonium iodide, m. 150°. Phenyldi[δ-methylamyl]phosphine (phenyldiisohexylphosphine), b50 219, results in 7 g. yield from 13 cc. PhPCl2; the phenylmethyl- and ethyldi-[δ-methylamyl]phosphonium iodides m. 146° and 116.5°, resp. p-Tolyldi-[δ-methylamyl]phosphine, b50 234-5°, d425 0.888; mercurichloride, m. 110.5°; methiodide, difficult to recrystallize. No tert. phosphine could be obtained when Grignard reagents from iso-PrBr and sec.-BuBr were employed.

      (a) Abrunhosa-Thomas, I.; Sellers, C. E.; Montchamp, J.-L. Alkylation of H-Phosphinate Esters under Basic Conditions. J. Org. Chem. 2007, 72, 2851– 2856,  DOI: 10.1021/jo062436o
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      42a
      Alkylation of H-Phosphinate Esters under Basic Conditions
      Abrunhosa-Thomas, Isabelle; Sellers, Claire E.; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72 (8), 2851-2856CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      An efficient and general procedure was developed for the direct alkylation of H-phosphinate esters with LHMDS at low temp. Alkylation of PhPH(O)(OEt) by RX promoted by lithium hexamethyldisilazide gave Ph(R)P(O)(OEt) (R = Me, C8H17, iPr; X = I, Br, Cl, OTs) with 77-100% yields. The masked hydrophosphinate reagent, MeC(OEt)2PH(O)(OEt), phosphinates R1PH(O)(OEt) [R1 = C8H17, Me, CH2:CHCH2, PrCH:C(Pr)] were also successfully alkylated in the same way. The simplicity of the reaction allows the use of various H-phosphinate esters and takes place with a wide range of electrophiles. The approach can be employed to access some GABA analogs or precursors to GABA analogs. The isolated yields are moderate to good. This is the first report of an alkylation with a secondary iodide or a primary chloride.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXislags7o%253D&md5=4534cef7b82236dac6a0775ebdd85d32
      .
      (b) Renard, P.-Y.; Vayron, P.; Leclerc, E.; Valleix, A.; Mioskowski, C. Lewis Acid Catalyzed Room-Temperature Michaelis–Arbuzov Rearrangement. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2003, 42, 2389– 2392,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.200250270
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      42b
      Lewis acid catalyzed room-temperature Michaelis-Arbuzov rearrangement
      Renard, Pierre-Yves; Vayron, Philippe; Leclerc, Eric; Valleix, Alain; Mioskowski, Charles
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (21), 2389-2392CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      It was demonstrated that use of an oxophilic Lewis acid, such as BF3.OEt2 or TMSOTf, could induce an Arbuzov-like rearrangement. The reaction conditions are particularly mild, since in most cases, room temp. or moderate heating are sufficient, which has not been described before for Arbuzov rearrangements. The scope of the reaction has been extended to phosphites, phosphinites, and phosphonites. Thus, TMSOTf-catalyzed Michaelis-Arbuzov rearrangement of Ph2P(OMe) in CHCl3 at 60° in 1h gave 98% Ph2(Me)P(O).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXkslektbY%253D&md5=1d76f8ff5a95521f28d3d8c041074c3e
      .
      (c) Berger, O.; Petit, C.; Deal, E. L.; Montchamp, J.-L. Phosphorus-Carbon Bond Formation: Palladium-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling of H-Phosphinates and Other P(O)H-Containing Compounds. Adv. Synth. Catal. 2013, 355, 1361– 1373,  DOI: 10.1002/adsc.201300069
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      42c
      Phosphorus-Carbon Bond Formation: Palladium-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling of H-Phosphinates and Other P(O)H-Containing Compounds
      Berger, Olivier; Petit, Christelle; Deal, Eric L.; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
      Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2013), 355 (7), 1361-1373CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two generally applicable systems were developed for the cross-coupling of P(O)H compds. with Csp2-X and related partners. Pd catalysis using a ligand/additive combination, typically either xantphos/ethylene glycol or 1,1'-bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene/1,2-dimethoxyethane, with diisopropylethylamine as the base, proved to be generally useful for the synthesis of numerous P-C contg. compds. E.g., reaction of RP(O)(OEt)H (R = octyl) with 2-bromopyridine in the presence of 2 mol% Pd(OAc)2/xantphos, toluene and ethylene glycol and (iPr)2NEt at 115° to give 93% yield of (Oct)P(O)(OEt)(2-pyridyl). Routinely, 2 mol% of catalyst are employed (less than half the amt. typically employed in most other literature reports). In most cases, excellent results were obtained with a variety of electrophiles (RX, where R = alkenyl, allyl, alkynyl, etc.). The full account of the studies is disclosed, including tandem hydrophosphinylation/coupling and coupling/coupling for doubly catalytic P-C bond formation. The methodol. compares favorably with any existing literature report. The use of an additive appears to be a generally useful strategy to control the reactivity of phosphinylidene compds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmvV2mu74%253D&md5=316c870d1860fa68ed8f7fb91f997252
      .

Tetrahedron Lett. 2001, 42, 453– 456,  DOI: 10.1016/S0040-4039(00)01950-X
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      42d
      Reactions of (RP)- and (SP)-tert-butylphenylphosphinobromidates and tert-butylphenylthionophosphinochloridates with heteroatom nucleophiles; preparation of P-chiral binol phosphinates and related compounds
      Au-Yeung, T.-L.; Chan, K.-Y.; Chan, W.-K.; Haynes, R. K.; Williams, I. D.; Yeung, L. L.
      Tetrahedron Letters (2001), 42 (3), 453-456CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      Reaction of (RP)- and (SP)-tert-butylphenylphosphinobromidates and tert-butylphenylthionophosphinochloridates with metalated phenol and BINOL alkoxides, thioalkoxides, amides and enolates leading with clean inversion at phosphorus to phosphinates, phosphinothiolates and phosphinoamidates, and the corresponding thionophosphorus compds. are described. Binol and other aryloxides, thioalkoxides and amides react with P-chiral halidates to form the title compds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      42e
      Synthesis of novel phosphorus heterocycles: 1,3-dihydro-2,1-benzoxaphosphole 1-oxides
      Miles, J. A.; Grabiak, R. C.; Cummins, C.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1982), 47 (9), 1677-82CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      A class of novel phosphorus heterocycles, 1,3-dihydro-2,1-benzoxaphosphole 1-oxides, has been prepd. by two different routes. One approach involves the cyclization of ortho-substituted phenylphosphinic acid derivs. under either thermal or solvolytic conditions. The other involves a novel metal-halogen exchange on the corresponding ortho-substituted aryl bromide with subsequent intramol. transposition of the P moiety.

      A review. Phys.-org. properties of the phosphonic acid group in connection to medicinal chem. aspects, together with an in depth review on advances and modern synthetic methods for its introduction compiled into sections with respect to substrate-carbon hybridization is presented.

      Qu, G.-R.; Xia, R.; Yang, X.-N.; Li, J.-G.; Wang, D.-C.; Guo, H.-M. Synthesis of Novel C6-Phosphonated Purine Nucleosides under Microwave Irradiation by SNAr–Arbuzov Reaction. J. Org. Chem. 2008, 73, 2416– 2419,  DOI: 10.1021/jo702680p
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44
      Synthesis of Novel C6-Phosphonated Purine Nucleosides under Microwave Irradiation by SNAr-Arbuzov Reaction
      Qu, Gui-Rong; Xia, Ran; Yang, Xi-Ning; Li, Jian-Guo; Wang, Dong-Chao; Guo, Hai-Ming
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73 (6), 2416-2419CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Novel C6-phosphonated purine nucleosides, e.g. I, were obtained in good to excellent isolated yields by the simple and catalyst-free SNAr-Arbuzov reaction of trialkyl phosphites with 6-chloropurine nucleosides, including a series of nonsugar carbon nucleosides. The reaction requires shorter reaction time and substantially higher yields under microwave irradn. conditions than conventional heating conditions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXisFWksb4%253D&md5=b91af111d2bb4d51f3969ceb6328a0a8
    45. 45
      Jiao, X.-Y.; Bentrude, W. G. A Facile Route to Vinyl- and Arylphosphonates by Vinyl and Aryl Radical Trapping with (MeO)3P. J. Org. Chem. 2003, 68, 3303– 3306,  DOI: 10.1021/jo020671a
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      45
      A Facile Route to Vinyl- and Arylphosphonates by Vinyl and Aryl Radical Trapping with (MeO)3P
      Jiao, Xian-Yun; Bentrude, Wesley G.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2003), 68 (8), 3303-3306CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      The generation of vinyl or aryl radicals under classical, thermal AIBN/n-Bu3SnH conditions at 80° in the presence of an excess of (MeO)3P gives rise to the corresponding vinyl- or arylphosphonates in 70-84% yields. Reactions with the individual stereoisomers of MeCH:CHMeBr (thermal AIBN/n-Bu3SnH conditions) afford a radical-equilibrated 96/4 E/Z ratio of vinylphosphonates. Substitution of (TMS)3SiH for n-Bu3SnH yields an approx. 1/1 ratio of separable E and Z vinylphosphonate diastereomers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitF2qsrs%253D&md5=2e9e9a4eb8991c518cf37ccd90cc7df3
    46. 46

      For seminal work see the following:

      (a) Tavs, P. Reaktion von Arylhalogeniden mit Trialkylphosphiten und Benzolphosphonigsäure-dialkylestern zu Aromatischen Phosphonsäureestern und Phosphinsäureestern unter Nickelsalzkatalyse. Chem. Ber. 1970, 103, 2428– 2436,  DOI: 10.1002/cber.19701030815
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46a
      Reaction of aryl halides with trialkyl phosphites or dialkyl phenylphosphonites to aromatic phosphonates or phosphinates by nickel salt catalyzed arylation
      Tavs, Peter
      Chemische Berichte (1970), 103 (8), 2428-36CODEN: CHBEAM; ISSN:0009-2940.
      Reaction of P(OEt)3 with RX at 150-70° in the presence of 5-10 mole % NiX2 under N gave 60-90% RP(O)(OEt)2 (I), where R = (substituted) phenyl, 2-naphthyl, or 2-thienyl, and X = Cl or Br. Similarly prepd. were (EtO)2P(O)C6H4P(O)OEt2 isomers and RPhP(O)OEt. Thus, P(OEt)3 was added dropwise to a suspension of NiCl2 in PhBr at 160°. EtBr distn. gave 91% I (R = Ph). A nonradical mechanism via a NiX2-phosphite complex was proposed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3cXkslOgsbg%253D&md5=3db03ca07f10ad6282455bd14354cf2e
      .

      For mechanistic studies see the following:

      (b) Balthazor, T. M.; Grabiak, R. C. Nickel-Catalyzed Arbuzov Reaction: Mechanistic Observations. J. Org. Chem. 1980, 45, 5425– 5426,  DOI: 10.1021/jo01314a059
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46b
      Nickel-catalyzed Arbuzov reaction: mechanistic observations
      Balthazor, Terry M.; Grabiak, Raymond C.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1980), 45 (26), 5425-6CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      The reaction of PhI and P(OEt)3 at 160° in the presence of a catalytic amt. of NiCl2 gives PhP(O)(OEt)2 in high yield. Evidence for the intermediacy of tetrakis(tri-Et phosphite)nickel (I) is presented. A competitive kinetic study of 3 substituted iodobenzenes is described. A mechanism involving rapid oxidative addn. of iodobenzene to I leading to ArNi[P(OEt)3]2I, followed by a slow decompn. to ArP+(OEt)3I- is proposed and discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3MXivFOksA%253D%253D&md5=35ed0051dc2aabf1a7ebe846d24ed09f
      .
      (c) Yang, G.; Shen, C.; Zhang, L.; Zhang, W. Nickel-Catalyzed Arbuzov Reactions of Aryl Triflates with Triethyl Phosphite. Tetrahedron Lett. 2011, 52, 5032– 5035,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tetlet.2011.07.077
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46c
      Nickel-catalyzed Arbuzov reactions of aryl triflates with triethyl phosphite
      Yang, Guoqiang; Shen, Chaoren; Zhang, Liang; Zhang, Wanbin
      Tetrahedron Letters (2011), 52 (39), 5032-5035CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      An efficient method was developed for the nickel-catalyzed phosphonylation of aryl triflates with tri-Et phosphite, in which KBr as an additive promoted the SN2 catalytic step. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of nickel-catalyzed Arbuzov reactions of aryl triflates. Most of the substrates showed good reactivity under this catalytic system.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtV2qtr%252FK&md5=36e6b386e91e477f63931a53ab7f5bf9

      Iranpoor, N.; Firouzabadi, H.; Moghadam, K. R.; Motavalli, S. First Reusable Ligand-free Palladium Catalyzed C–P Bond Formation of Aryl Halides with Trialkylphosphites in Neat Water. RSC Adv. 2014, 4, 55732– 55737,  DOI: 10.1039/C4RA07680J
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      47
      First reusable ligand-free palladium catalyzed C-P bond formation of aryl halides with trialkylphosphites in neat water
      Iranpoor, Nasser; Firouzabadi, Habib; Moghadam, Khashayar Rajabi; Motavalli, Somayeh
      RSC Advances (2014), 4 (99), 55732-55737CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A reusable ligand-free palladium catalyzed phosphonation of aryl iodides, bromides and chlorides with trialkylphosphites is described for the first time in neat water. The aryl phosphonates are obtained in good to excellent yields. The reaction can be also performed with Ni(II) with longer reaction time. The role of tetrabutylammonium bromide in this reaction as reducing agent for generation of Pd(0) at room temp. is also demonstrated. Pd(0)/TBAB was easily reused for three runs without decreasing the efficiency.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslaisrfP&md5=d03643ee29a8b8176bd5e4306e3e28c6
    48. 48

      For a recent example see the following:

      Ballester, J.; Gatignol, J.; Schmidt, G.; Alayrac, C.; Gaumont, A.-C.; Taillefer, M. A Copper-Catalyzed Variant of the Michaelis–Arbuzov Reaction. ChemCatChem 2014, 6, 1549– 1552,  DOI: 10.1002/cctc.201301029
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      48
      A Copper-Catalyzed Variant of the Michaelis-Arbuzov Reaction
      Ballester, Jorge; Gatignol, Jeremie; Schmidt, Guntram; Alayrac, Carole; Gaumont, Annie-Claude; Taillefer, Marc
      ChemCatChem (2014), 6 (6), 1549-1552CODEN: CHEMK3; ISSN:1867-3880. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      As part of our studies on copper-catalyzed arylation of nucleophiles, authors report on Michaelis-Arbuzov reactions with a novel catalytic system, featuring a copper(I) salt as precatalyst without any addnl. ligand. This procedure is an interesting alternative to the use of expensive and toxic transition metals (nickel, palladium) traditionally used as catalysts in Michaelis-Arbuzov reactions. The approach allows the synthesis from tri-Et phosphite, di-Et aryl phosphonite, and diaryl ethylphosphinite of various aryl phosphonates, aryl phosphinates, and aryl phosphine oxides, resp. These families of compds. are essential owing to their resp. importance in bioorg. and medical chem., their applicability as flame retardants, and their usability in coordination chem. and catalysis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXmtVChuro%253D&md5=c0fda6e61015b21d0570c4262092cf6d

      Shaikh, R. S.; Düsel, S. J. S.; König, B. Visible-Light Photo-Arbuzov Reaction of Aryl Bromides and Trialkyl Phosphites Yielding Aryl Phosphonates. ACS Catal. 2016, 6, 8410– 8414,  DOI: 10.1021/acscatal.6b02591
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      49
      Visible-Light Photo-Arbuzov Reaction of Aryl Bromides and Trialkyl Phosphites Yielding Aryl Phosphonates
      Shaikh, Rizwan S.; Duesel, Simon J. S.; Koenig, Burkhard
      ACS Catalysis (2016), 6 (12), 8410-8414CODEN: ACCACS; ISSN:2155-5435. (American Chemical Society)
      Photocatalytic Arbuzov phosphonylation of aryl bromides was achieved under blue light irradn. and rhodamine 6G catalysis, yielding a wide range of arylphosphonates. Aryl phosphonates are functional groups frequently found in pharmaceutical and crop protection agents. For their synthesis via C-P bond formation typically transition metal catalyzed reactions are used. We report a visible light photo-Arbuzov reaction as an efficient, mild and metal-free alternative. Rhodamine 6G (Rh.6G) is used as photocatalyst generating aryl radicals under blue light. Coupling of the radicals with a wide range of trivalent phosphites gives aryl phosphonates in good to very good isolated yields. The mild reaction conditions allow the introduction of a phosphonate group into complex and sensitive pharmaceutically active mols., such as benzodiazepams or nicergoline by the activation of a carbon halogen bond.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVehs7rP&md5=5b67278c4c504eb53f80d6c9076b4cb3

      50b
      Revisiting the Hirao cross-coupling: improved synthesis of aryl and heteroaryl phosphonates
      Belabassi, Yamina; Alzghari, Saeed; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
      Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (2008), 693 (19), 3171-3178CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling of dialkylphosphite with arom. electrophiles (Hirao coupling) was re-investigated. Some limitations in terms of palladium loadings and substrate reactivity are alleviated with the use of Pd(OAc)2 complexed to 1,1'-bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene (dppf) as a ligand. Various aryl and heteroaryl halides are employed to deliver both known and novel substituted phosphonates. The first examples of aryl chloride couplings are also reported.

      Development of a room temperature Hirao reaction
      Kohler, Mark C.; Sokol, Joseph G.; Stockland, Robert A.
      Tetrahedron Letters (2009), 50 (4), 457-459CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Arylphosphonates, RC6H4P(O)(OEt)2 (R = 4-MeO, 4-Me, H, 4-NC, 4-C(O)Me, 4-OH, 4-Cl, 2-OMe, 4-NH2), were prepd. at 25° through the Pd-catalyzed coupling of aryl iodides, RC6H4I, with a Ag phosphonate, Ag[P(O)(OEt)2]. A wide range of aryl iodides were successfully employed including phenolic substrates as well as those contg. an ortho substituent.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsFWjurfF&md5=cc4c5b74c0f3dff0173c82232dcf50e1

      (d) Zhao, Y.-L.; Wu, G.-J.; Li, Y.; Gao, L.-X.; Han, F.-S. [NiCl2(dppp)]-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling of Aryl Halides with Dialkyl Phosphite, Diphenylphosphine Oxide, and Diphenylphosphine. Chem. - Eur. J. 2012, 18, 9622– 9627,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201103723
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      50d
      NiCl2(dppp)-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling of Aryl Halides with Dialkyl Phosphite, Diphenylphosphine Oxide, and Diphenylphosphine
      Zhao, Yu-Long; Wu, Guo-Jie; Li, You; Gao, Lian-Xun; Han, Fu-She
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (31), 9622-9627, S9622/1-S9622/51CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      We present a general approach to C-P bond formation through the cross-coupling of aryl halides with a dialkyl phosphite, diphenylphosphine oxide, and diphenylphosphine by using [NiCl2(dppp)] as catalyst (dppp = 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane). This catalyst system displays a broad applicability that is capable of catalyzing the cross-coupling of aryl bromides, particularly a range of unreactive aryl chlorides, with various types of phosphorus substrates, such as a dialkyl phosphite, diphenylphosphine oxide, and diphenylphosphine. Consequently, the synthesis of valuable phosphonates, phosphine oxides, and phosphines can be achieved with one catalyst system. Moreover, the reaction proceeds not only at a much lower temp. (100-120 °C) relative to the classic Arbuzov reaction (ca. 160-220 °C), but also without the need of external reductants and supporting ligands. In addn., owing to the relatively mild reaction conditions, a range of labile groups, such as ether, ester, ketone, and cyano groups, are tolerated. Finally, a brief mechanistic study revealed that by using [NiCl2(dppp)] as a catalyst, the NiII center could be readily reduced in situ to Ni0 by the phosphorus substrates due to the influence of the dppp ligand, thereby facilitating the oxidative addn. of aryl halides to a Ni0 center. This step is the key to bringing the reaction into the catalytic cycle.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XpsFSjtb0%253D&md5=0addcc9a611509c4bee67d027e69573c

      Fu, W. C.; So, C. M.; Kwong, F. Y. Palladium-Catalyzed Phosphorylation of Aryl Mesylates and Tosylates. Org. Lett. 2015, 17, 5906– 5909,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.orglett.5b03104
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      51
      Palladium-Catalyzed Phosphorylation of Aryl Mesylates and Tosylates
      Fu, Wai Chung; So, Chau Ming; Kwong, Fuk Yee
      Organic Letters (2015), 17 (23), 5906-5909CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      The first general palladium catalyst for the phosphorylation of aryl mesylates and tosylates is reported. The newly developed system exhibits excellent functional group compatibility. For instance, free amino, keto, ester, and amido groups, as well as heterocycles, remain intact during the course of reaction. The mesylated derivs. of biol. active compds. such as 17β-estradiol and 6-hydroxyflavone are also shown to be applicable substrates. A one-pot phosphorylation-amination sequence is described for the facile synthesis of potential pharmacophores.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      52a
      Decarbonylative C-P Bond Formation Using Aromatic Esters and Organophosphorus Compounds
      Isshiki, Ryota; Muto, Kei; Yamaguchi, Junichiro
      Organic Letters (2018), 20 (4), 1150-1153CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      Ni-catalyzed C-P bond formation was achieved using arom. esters as unconventional aryl sources. The key to success was the use of the thiophene-based diphosphine ligand 3,4-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)thiophene (dcypt). Several arom. esters including heteroaroms. can be coupled with phosphine oxides and phosphonates, providing aryl P compds. The synthetic utility of the method was demonstrated by application of the present protocol to sequential coupling reactions.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitVamtr4%253D&md5=1150ac4b0565eb14095757c194b3f98d

      (b) Liu, C.; Szostak, M. Decarbonylative Phosphorylation of Amides by Palladium and Nickel Catalysis: The Hirao Cross-Coupling of Amide Derivatives. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2017, 56, 12718– 12722,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201707102
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      52b
      Decarbonylative phosphorylation of amides by palladium and nickel catalysis: the Hirao cross-coupling of amide derivatives
      Liu, Chengwei; Szostak, Michal
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2017), 56 (41), 12718-12722CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Considering the ubiquity of organophosphorus compds. in org. synthesis, pharmaceutical discovery agrochem. crop protection and materials chem., new methods for their construction hold particular significance. A conventional method for the synthesis of C-P bonds involves cross-coupling of aryl halides and dialkyl phosphites (the Hirao reaction). We report a catalytic deamidative phosphorylation of a wide range of amides using a palladium or nickel catalyst giving aryl phosphonates in good to excellent yields. The present method tolerates a wide range of functional groups. The reaction constitutes the first example of a transition-metal-catalyzed generation of C-P bonds from amides. This redox-neutral protocol can be combined with site-selective conventional cross-coupling for the regioselective synthesis of potential pharmacophores. Mechanistic studies suggest an oxidative addn./transmetallation pathway. In light of the importance of amides and phosphonates as synthetic intermediates, we envision that this Pd and Ni-catalyzed C-P bond forming method will find broad application.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsVekt7rL&md5=4b7a1c56ae0f7c78efe179de29376c34

      (a) Shaikh, R. S.; Ghosh, I.; König, B. Direct C–H Phosphonylation of Electron-Rich Arenes and Heteroarenes by Visible-Light Photoredox Catalysis. Chem. - Eur. J. 2017, 23, 12120– 12124,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201701283
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      56a
      Direct C-H Phosphonylation of Electron-Rich Arenes and Heteroarenes by Visible-Light Photoredox Catalysis
      Shaikh, Rizwan S.; Ghosh, Indrajit; Koenig, Burkhard
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2017), 23 (50), 12120-12124CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The direct transformation of ubiquitous, but chem. inert C-H bonds into diverse functional groups is an important strategy in org. synthesis that improves the atom economy and facilitates the prepn. and modification of complex mols. In contrast to the wide applications of aryl phosphonates, their synthesis via direct C-H bond phosphonylation is a less explored area. It is reported here a general, mild, and broadly applicable visible-light photoredox C-H bond phosphonylation method for electron-rich arenes and heteroarenes. The photoredox catalytic protocol utilizes electron-rich arenes and biol. important heteroarenes as substrates, [Ru(bpz)3][PF6]2 as photocatalyst, ammonium persulfate as oxidant, and trialkyl phosphites as the phosphorus source to provide a wide range of aryl phosphonates at ambient temp. under very mild reaction conditions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlvVeltLw%253D&md5=8323725227580e89650bd90e71d714b5
      .
      (b) Niu, L.; Liu, J.; Yi, H.; Wang, S.; Liang, X.-A.; Singh, A. K.; Chiang, C.-W.; Lei, A. Visible-Light-Induced External Oxidant-Free Oxidative Phosphonylation of C(sp2)–H Bonds. ACS Catal. 2017, 7, 7412– 7416,  DOI: 10.1021/acscatal.7b02418
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      56b
      Visible-Light-Induced External Oxidant-Free Oxidative Phosphonylation of C(sp2)-H Bonds
      Niu, Linbin; Liu, Jiamei; Yi, Hong; Wang, Shengchun; Liang, Xing-An; Singh, Atul K.; Chiang, Chien-Wei; Lei, Aiwen
      ACS Catalysis (2017), 7 (11), 7412-7416CODEN: ACCACS; ISSN:2155-5435. (American Chemical Society)
      Considering the synthetic value of phosphonates, developing powerful catalytic methods for the phosphonylation of C(sp2)-H bonds is important. Herein, we achieve a visible-light-induced external oxidant-free oxidative phosphonylation of C(sp2)-H bonds via the combination of photocatalysis and proton-redn. catalysis. Mechanistic studies indicate that the visible-light-induced electron-rich arene radical cation is the key reactive intermediate. The synthetic application of this approach is demonstrated in the late-stage functionalization of pharmaceutical mols. This study may have significant implications for the functionalization of C(sp2)-H bonds, esp. for those that are sensitive to oxidative conditions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsFOjt7bL&md5=56d745a931b3b6db691c8f0898ffaf6c

      (a) Burger, A.; Dawson, N. D. The Reaction of Dialkyl Chlorophosphates with Arylmagnesium Halides. J. Org. Chem. 1951, 16, 1250– 1254,  DOI: 10.1021/jo50002a010
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57a
      The reaction of dialkyl chlorophosphates with arylmagnesium halides
      Burger, Alfred; Dawson, Norman D.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1951), 16 (), 1250-4CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      o-Substituted arylmagnesium halides react with Ar2POCl with the formation of arom. phosphonic acids (I), whereas sterically unhindered Grignard compds. are converted to Ar3PO. By a reversed Grignard reaction with sterically unhindered ArMgX and (RO)2POCl, I are obtained. Adding dropwise 5.7 g. (EtO)2POCl (II) in 50 cc. ether to p-ClC6H4MgBr from 19.1 g. bromide in 80 cc. ether with ice cooling and vigorous stirring causes a strong reaction. The mixt. is then refluxed 2 h., cooled, decompd. with ice and dil. HCl, and extd. with ether, and the dried ether ext. evapd., giving 54% (p-ClC6H4)3PO, crystals, from dil. EtOH, m. 178°. In a similar way the following Ar3PO are prepd.: Ar = Ph, 73% yield, m. 156.5-8°; p-MeC6H4, 75.5%, m. 143-4°; 2-C10H7, 66%, m. 248-9°; 2-thienyl, 75%, m. 129-30°; p-PhC6H4, 33%, m. 233-4°. Adding dropwise 17.2 g. II in 50 cc. ether to o-MeC6H4MgBr from 18.8 g. bromide with ice cooling and stirring in a N atm., refluxing the mixt. 2 h., and decompg. the cooled mixt. with iced HCl give 50.4% o-MeC6H4PO(OEt)2, b14 148-50°, which, hydrolyzed with concd. HCl, gives o-MeC6H4PO3H2, m. 139-41°. In the same way are prepd.: 1-C10H7PO3H, 45% yield, m. 199-200°; o-Ph-C6H4PO3H2, 31.4%, m. 203-5°; o-ClC6H4PO3H2, 26.1%, m. 181-3°; p-ClC6H4PO3H2 (III), 48%, m. 186-7°. PhPO3H2 (IV) is prepd. by a reversed Grignard reaction: PhMgBr from 7.8 g. PhBr in 200 cc. ether is added dropwise over a period of 2.25 h. to 8.5 g. II in 200 cc. ether with gentle boiling, the mixt. kept overnight and decompd. with iced dil. HCl, giving 40.5% PhPO(OEt)2 which, hydrolyzed with concd. HCl, gives IV, m. 161-3°; it is also obtained on catalytic redn. of III with Pd-carbon. In lieu of ArMgX, ArLi may be used: p-MeC6H4Li (from 8.5 g. p-MeC6H4Br) in 200 cc. ether is added dropwise within 2.5 h. to a stirred and refluxing soln. of 8.5 g. II in 200 cc. ether and the mixt. decompd. with iced HCl, giving 55% p-MeC6H4PO(OEt)2, b1 122°, which, hydrolyzed, gives 3.2 g. p-MeC6H4PO(OH)2, fine needles, m. 188.5-90°.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG38XhslGmsw%253D%253D&md5=930dde32af47a1779c6270768a2c8820
      .
      (b) Van Overtveldt, M.; Heugebaert, T. S. A.; Verstraeten, I.; Geelen, D.; Stevens, C. V. Phosphonamide Pyrabactin Analogues as Abscisic Acid Agonists. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2015, 13, 5260– 5264,  DOI: 10.1039/C5OB00137D
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57b
      Phosphonamide pyrabactin analogues as abscisic acid agonists
      Van Overtveldt, M.; Heugebaert, T. S. A.; Verstraeten, I.; Geelen, D.; Stevens, C. V.
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2015), 13 (18), 5260-5264CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A four step synthesis towards novel phosphonic pyrabactin analogs is presented. Via a stomatal closure and germination assay, the ability of the analogs to selectively induce the ABA-signaling pathway was demonstrated.

      Intramolecular coordination at phosphorus: donor-acceptor interaction in three- and four-coordinated phosphorus compounds
      Carre, Francis; Chuit, Claude; Corriu, Robert J. P.; Monforte, Pascal; Nayyar, Naresh K.; Reye, Catherine
      Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (1995), 499 (1-2), 147-54CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier)
      The P derivs. P(X)(O2C6H4-1,2)[C6H4(CH2NMe2)-2] (9-11) (shown as structure I, X = -, O, S) undergo ready extension of coordination by N→P intramol. donor-acceptor interaction as shown by 31P NMR and dynamic 1H NMR spectroscopy. This extension of coordination does not occur with P(X)(OEt)2[C6H4(CH2NMe2)-2] (X = O 7, S 8). The ΔG⧧ of pseudo-rotation was calcd. by dynamic 1H NMR spectroscopy to be 57-58 kJ mol-1 for the three compds. P(X)(O2C6H4-1,2)[C10H6(NMe2-8)] (19-21) (shown as structure II, X = -, O, S).

      58b
      Cyclic organophosphorus compounds. IV. Cleavage of 1,3,2-dioxaphospholane and 1,3,2-dioxaphosphorinane rings by Grignard reagents
      Edmundson, Ronald S.; Wrigley, J. O. L.
      Tetrahedron (1967), 23 (1), 283-90CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020.
      cf. CA 63, 17875h. Cyclic phosphorochloridates (e.g. I) and phenylphosphonates based on the 1,3,2-dioxaphospholane and 1,3,2-dioxaphosphorinane ring systems, undergo ring cleavage when treated with phenylmagnesium halides, to yield ω-hydroxyalkyl diphenylphosphinic esters, and ultimately, triphenylphosphine oxide. In the case of the smaller ring, diphenylphosphinic acid is a major product of the reaction. Possible mechanisms for these reactions are discussed.

      Synthesis and antimicrobial activity of novel 3 substituted 1,5-dihydro-2,4,3-benzodioxaphosphepine 3-oxides
      Haranath, P.; Babu, M. F. Stephen; Anasuyamma, U.; Raju, C. Naga; Reddy, C. Suresh
      Heteroatom Chemistry (2005), 16 (7), 572-575CODEN: HETCE8; ISSN:1042-7163. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      Novel 3-R-1,5-dihydro-2,4,3-benzo[e][1,3,2]-dioxaphosphepin 3-oxides (5a-h; R = Me, Et, n-Pr, iPr, Bu, CH:CH2, CH2CH:CH2, CH2CH2Cl, Ph) were prepd. by reaction of 1,2-benzenedimethanol (1) with phosphorus tribromide in the presence of triethylamine at 0-30° with subsequent Grignard alkylation of the monobromide (2) and oxidn. by H2O2. The chem. structures of all the products were confirmed by anal., IR and NMR (1H, 13C, and 31P) spectral data. Their antifungal and antibacterial activity is also evaluated. Most of these compds. exhibited moderate antimicrobial activity against Aspergillus niger, Helminthosporium oryzae, Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus.

      59
      Synthesis and conformational study of P-heterocyclic androst-5-ene derivatives
      Frank, Eva; Schafer, Balazs; Mucsi, Zoltan; Keglevich, Gyorgy
      Heteroatom Chemistry (2008), 19 (1), 7-14CODEN: HETCE8; ISSN:1042-7163. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      The reactions of (20R)-3β-acetoxy-21-(hydroxymethyl)pregn-5-en-20-ol and (20R)-3β-acetoxypregn-5-ene-20,21-diol with phenylphosphonic dichloride and aryl dichlorophosphates YP(O)Cl2 (Y = PhO, 4-ClC6H4O, 4-O2NC6H4O) afforded novel types of P-heterocyclic androst-5-ene derivs. I (Y = Ph, PhO, 4-ClC6H4O, 4-O2NC6H4O) and II as epimeric pairs. The diastereomers were sepd. by column chromatog. and were characterized by NMR spectroscopy. Estn. of the stereostructures of the corresponding epimers by B3LYP/631G(d) DFT ab initio calcns. suggested that the six-membered hetero ring in compds. I (Y = α-Ph) and I (Y = β-PhO, β-4-ClC6H4O, β-4-O2NC6H4O) adopts predominantly a chair conformation, with the P-substituents in their preferred orientation. The cyclic phosphonate moiety in I (Y = β-Ph) or I (Y = α-PhO, α-4-ClC6H4O, α-4-O2NC6H4O), however, seems to exist as an equil. mixt. of chair-distorted-boat or chair-chair forms. The theor. calcns. indicate that the conformational equil. is shifted toward the distorted-boat conformer for I (Y = β-Ph), with a pseudoequatorial P-Ph substituent, whereas for I (Y = α-PhO, α-4-ClC6H4O, α-4-O2NC6H4O) the chair conformer with an equatorial P-phenoxy group predominates.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhvVOktbY%253D&md5=304c7ffa0415b4f749168ecdd78ecbcf

      60
      Cyclic phosphinamides and phosphonamides, novel series of potent matrix metalloproteinase inhibitors with antitumour activity
      Sorensen, Morten Dahl; Blaehr, Lars K. A.; Christensen, Mette K.; Hoyer, Thomas; Latini, Scilla; Hjarnaa, Pernille-Julia V.; Bjorkling, Fredrik
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2003), 11 (24), 5461-5484CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The design, synthesis, and structure-activity relationship (SAR) of a series of novel nonpeptidic cyclic phosphon- and phosphinamide-based hydroxamic acids as inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases MMP-1, MMP-3, and MMP-9 are presented. Heterocyclization of R3O2CCHR1NHCH2(CH2)nCH2OH with R2POCl2 (R1 = alkyl, H; R2 = 4-substituted phenyl; R3 = Me, Et) followed by hydrolysis of heterocyclic esters (28a-x) gave cyclic phosphonamides: 3-HO2CCHR1-2-R2-2-oxo-1,3,2-oxazaphosphorinanes (291-e, r, u, w), 3-HO2CCHR1-2-R2-2-oxo-1,3,2-oxazaphosphepanes (29f-q), 3-HO2CCHR1-2-R2-2-oxo-1,3,2-oxazaphosphocanes (29s,v,x) and 3-HO2CCHR1-2-R2-2-oxo-1,3,2-oxazaphosphonane (29t). Reaction of carboxylic acids 29 with iso-Bu chloroformate and O-trimethylsilyl hydroxylamine or hydroxyaminolysis of esters 28 by O-trimethylsilyl hydroxylamine provided corresponding hydroxamic acids, 3-HONHCOCHR1-2-R2-2-oxo-1,3,2-oxazaphosphorinanes, -oxazaphosphepanes, -oxazaphosphocanes and -oxazaphosphonane, resp. (4a-x). The prepd. cyclic phosphonamides were tested in vitro for matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) inhibition. Based on modeling studies and x-ray anal., a model of the binding mode of these novel compds. in the MMP active site was obtained. This model provided a rational explanation for the obsd. SAR data, which included a systematic study of different S1' directed substituents, zinc-complexing groups, chirality, and variation of the cyclic phosphon- and phosphinamide rings. The in vivo effect of four compds. in a human fibrosarcoma mouse model (HT1080) was evaluated and compared to that of a ref. compd., Prinomastat. Inhibition of tumor growth was obsd. for all four compds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpt1ensro%253D&md5=76967547d428f23bb76f4a1d531e9d6c

      (a) Burns, B.; King, N. P.; Tye, H.; Studley, J. R.; Gamble, M.; Wills, M. Chiral Phosphinamides: New Catalysts for the Asymmetric Reduction of Ketones by Borane. J. Chem. Soc., Perkin Trans. 1 1998, 1027– 1038,  DOI: 10.1039/a709174e
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      61a
      Chiral phosphinamides: new catalysts for the asymmetric reduction of ketones by borane
      Burns, Barry; King, N. Paul; Tye, Heather; Studley, John R.; Gamble, Mark; Wills, Martin
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Perkin Transactions 1: Organic and Bio-Organic Chemistry (1998), (6), 1027-1038CODEN: JCPRB4; ISSN:0300-922X. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A new class of catalysts for the asym. redn. of prochiral ketones by borane was identified. Key to the architecture of effective catalysts is an N-P:O structural unit which may be part of a phosphinamide, phosphonamide or a related structure. Such catalysts are simple to prep., are often cryst. solids and may be recovered from redn. reactions and reused. The catalysts act essentially as Lewis bases, serving to increase the reactivity of borane by electron donation. The incorporation of a hydroxy group into the catalyst provides an adjacent Lewis acid site upon reaction with borane and thus affords a superior catalyst capable of asym. inductions of up to 92% ee.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXhsVykurc%253D&md5=a3eaeb0bdcb2a5e8269f422286473afa
      .
      (b) Núñez, A.; Berroterán, D.; Núñez, O. Hydrolysis of Cyclic Phosphoramides. Evidence for syn Lone Pair Catalysis. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2003, 1, 2283– 2289,  DOI: 10.1039/B300916E
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      61b
      Hydrolysis of cyclic phosphoramides. Evidence for syn lone pair catalysis
      Nunez, Andres; Berroteran, Dyanna; Nunez, Oswaldo
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2003), 1 (13), 2283-2289CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Hydrolysis between 1.5 < pH < 4 of five- and six-membered cyclic phosphoramides was followed by UV and NMR 31P spectroscopy. The obsd. rates fit the equation: kobs = kH2O·[H+]/([H+] + Ka) + k'H2O, where kH2O and k'H2O are the pseudo first-order rate consts. of water attack on the protonated phosphoramide and its unprotonated form, resp., and Ka is the phosphoramide acidity equil. const. Although, faster hydrolysis rates on the five membered ring are expected due to the cyclic strain energy release in formation of a "strained free" trigonal-bipyramidal-pentacoordinated intermediate, in which one of the cyclic nitrogens occupy the apical position, the values of kH2O are only slightly higher, than for the corresponding six-membered analogs, whereas the k'H2O values were lower. The balance in reactivity is attributed to the addnl. stability gained in the six-membered rings by a syn orientation of the two lone pairs of the cyclic nitrogens to the water attack. This stabilization does not exist in the five membered phospholidines since the water attack is perpendicular to the electron pairs of the cyclic nitrogen atoms. In agreement with the incoming water orientation, the main products of the hydrolysis of the phospholidines arise from the endocyclic bond cleavage, whereas the diazaphosphorinanes gave the kinetic products originating from the exocyclic cleavage. The syn orientation of two electron pairs on nitrogen stabilizes the transition state of water approach to the phosphoramides by ca. 3 kcal mol-1 when compared to the orthogonal attack.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXkvFWqsrg%253D&md5=ac76676d3592dc741f0234bc976c1b31

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62c
      Double Arbuzov Reaction of in Situ Generated Bis(trimethylsiloxy)phosphine with Dielectrophiles: Methodology for the Synthesis of Cyclic Phosphinic Acids
      Montchamp, Jean-Luc; Tian, Feng; Frost, J. W.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1995), 60 (19), 6076-81CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Phosphetanic, phospholanic, phosphorinanic, phosphepanic, and phosphocanic acid derivs. have been prepd. in a single step by the double Arbuzov reaction of bis(trimethylsiloxy)phosphine (BTSP) with dielectrophiles. Mild, thermal reaction conditions are employed during reaction of BTSP with 1,n-dihaloalkanes (n = 3-7), a ditriflate, and ω-bromo-1,2-epoxides possessing varying levels of steric congestion and functionalization. Isolation and manipulation of pyrophoric BTSP is avoided with in situ generation of the reagent from ammonium hypophosphite and hexamethyldisilazane. Monocyclic, bicyclic, and spirocyclic phosphinic acids are obtained after purifn. in moderate to good isolated yields. The developed methodol. is of particular interest for synthesis of nonhydrolizable analogs of cyclic phosphodiesters.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXnslyisrw%253D&md5=55b2c0dc3f44540a6132212acba50613

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62d
      A Highly Efficient and Practical Synthesis of Cyclic Phosphinates Using Ring-Closing Metathesis
      Bujard, M.; Gouverneur, V.; Mioskowski, C.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1999), 64 (6), 2119-2123CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      The efficiency of the catalytic ring-closing metathesis combined with the ease of prepn. of the dienes makes this methodol. an attractive alternative to the formation of differently substituted five-, six-, and seven-membered phosphinates. This is the first report related to the metathesis of dienes including a phosphinate function. Further work is presently underway in our lab. to extend this novel strategy to the synthesis of more functionalized and biol. active phosphorus contg. heterocycles.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62e
      Hydrophosphinylation of Unactivated Terminal Alkenes Catalyzed by Nickel Chloride
      Ortial, Stephanie; Fisher, Henry C.; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 78 (13), 6599-6608CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      The room-temp. hydrophosphinylation of unactivated monosubstituted alkenes using phosphinates (ROP(O)H2) and catalytic NiCl2 in the presence of dppe is described. The method is competitive with prior palladium-catalyzed reactions and uses a much cheaper catalyst and simple conditions. The scope of the reaction is quite broad in terms of unactivated terminal olefins, proceeds at room temp., often avoids chromatog. purifn., and allows one-pot conversion to various organophosphorus compds.

      62f
      Phosphinate-containing heterocycles: a mini-review
      Berger, Olivier; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
      Beilstein Journal of Organic Chemistry (2014), 10 (), 732-740, 9 pp.CODEN: BJOCBH; ISSN:1860-5397. (Beilstein-Institut zur Foerderung der Chemischen Wissenschaften)
      A review. This review provides an overview of recent efforts towards the synthesis of phosphinate heterocycles R1R2P(O)(OR). The authors and others have been involved in this field, and as a result, new P-C, P-N, and P-O contg. heterocyclic motifs are now available through a variety of methods. While developing rapidly, this area is still in its infancy so that biol. testing of the compds. has not yet been conducted and applications are rare. The growing availability of synthetic methods will undoubtedly change this situation in the near future.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXptVygu7w%253D&md5=5919187979311e82e15a0184fd9df2e2
