        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        62f
        Phosphinate-containing heterocycles: a mini-review
        Berger, Olivier; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
        Beilstein Journal of Organic Chemistry (2014), 10 (), 732-740, 9 pp.CODEN: BJOCBH; ISSN:1860-5397. (Beilstein-Institut zur Foerderung der Chemischen Wissenschaften)
        A review. This review provides an overview of recent efforts towards the synthesis of phosphinate heterocycles R1R2P(O)(OR). The authors and others have been involved in this field, and as a result, new P-C, P-N, and P-O contg. heterocyclic motifs are now available through a variety of methods. While developing rapidly, this area is still in its infancy so that biol. testing of the compds. has not yet been conducted and applications are rare. The growing availability of synthetic methods will undoubtedly change this situation in the near future.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXptVygu7w%253D&md5=5919187979311e82e15a0184fd9df2e2
      63. 63
        Tang, W.; Sarvestani, M.; Wei, X.; Nummy, L. J.; Patel, N.; Narayanan, B.; Byrne, D.; Lee, H.; Yee, N. K.; Senanayake, C. H. Formation of 2-Trifluoromethylphenyl Grignard Reagent via Magnesium–Halogen Exchange: Process Safety Evaluation and Concentration Effect. Org. Process Res. Dev. 2009, 13, 1426– 1430,  DOI: 10.1021/op900040y
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        63
        Formation of 2-Trifluoromethylphenyl Grignard Reagent via Magnesium-Halogen Exchange: Process Safety Evaluation and Concentration Effect
        Tang, Wenjun; Sarvestani, Max; Wei, Xudong; Nummy, Laurence J.; Patel, Nitinchandra; Narayanan, Bikshandarkoil; Byrne, Denis; Lee, Heewon; Yee, Nathan K.; Senanayake, Chris H.
        Organic Process Research & Development (2009), 13 (6), 1426-1430CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
        The thermal stability profile for a soln. of 2-trifluoromethylphenyl magnesium chloride at 1.5 M concn. in THF was detd. using an Advanced Reactive System Screening Tool (ARSST). The soln. generated by employing Knochel's magnesium-halogen exchange protocol showed highly exothermic decompn. The decompn. begins at a low-onset temp. accompanied by a rapid temp. and pressure rise. Anal. of the decompn. mixt. revealed the destruction of trifluoromethyl group and formation of fluoride ion. This decompn. profile was substantially attenuated by reducing the concn. of the soln. to 0.5-0.6 M. Thus, it is strongly recommended that selecting an appropriate concn. for the reagent based on calorimetric evaluation should be included with procedural and engineering controls when considering any strategy for safe scale-up of trifluoromethyl-substituted Ph Grignard solns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXns1OnsL4%253D&md5=bff897ed7c8845bff758006c2f2d4e64
      64. 64

        For the preparation of ethyl divinylphosphinate, see the following:

        (a) Maier, L. Organische Phosphorverbindungen 44 Darstellung und Eigenschaften von Bis-(β-chloräthyl)-phosphinsäure-Derivaten [1]. Helv. Chim. Acta 1971, 54, 275– 277,  DOI: 10.1002/hlca.19710540124
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        64a
        Organic phosphorus compounds. 44. Preparation and properties of bis(β-chloroethyl)phosphinic acid derivatives
        Maier, Ludwig
        Helvetica Chimica Acta (1971), 54 (1), 275-7CODEN: HCACAV; ISSN:0018-019X.
        The reaction of ClCH2CH2PCl2 with ethylene oxide gave the phosphonous acid ester ClCH2CH2P(OCH2CH2Cl)2, which upon heating to 120° rearranged to the phosphinic acid ester (ClCH2CH2)2P(O)OCH2CH2Cl (I). The chlorination of I with PCl5 in CCl4 yielded (ClCH2CH2)2P(O)Cl (II), which upon treatment with P2S5 at 170° produced (ClCH2CH2)2P(S)Cl (III). The treatment of II and III with alcs., mercaptans or amines, in the presence of an acid, led to the corresponding phosphinic and thiophosphinic acid derivs., (ClCH2CH2)2P(X)Y, (IV) (X = O, or S, Y = OR, SR, or NR2, R = alkyl or aryl). The reaction of IV with excess base yielded the corresponding divinylphosphinic acid and divinylthiophosphinic acid derivs. (CH2:CH)2P(X)Y. Bis-(β-chloroethyl)phosphinates, e.g. (ClCH2CH2)2P(O)OEt underwent a Michaelis-Arbuzov reaction when heated with phosphites to 160-70° to give bis(phosphonylethyl)phosphinates e.g. (EtO)(O)P[CH2CH2P(O)(OEt)2]2, which upon hydrolysis with concd. HCl yielded HO2P(CH2CH2PO3H2)2.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3MXmsVarsw%253D%253D&md5=836f5cdc1ee22f288ce7b0d74345b3d2
        .
        (b) Dunne, K. S.; Bisaro, F.; Odell, B.; Paris, J.-M.; Gouverneur, V. Diastereoselective Ring-Closing Metathesis: Synthesis of P-Stereogenic Phosphinates from Prochiral Phosphinic Acid Derivatives. J. Org. Chem. 2005, 70, 10803– 10809,  DOI: 10.1021/jo0518708
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        64b
        Diastereoselective Ring-Closing Metathesis: Synthesis of P-Stereogenic Phosphinates from Prochiral Phosphinic Acid Derivatives
        Dunne, Katherine S.; Bisaro, Fabrice; Odell, Barbara; Paris, Jean-Marc; Gouverneur, Veronique
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2005), 70 (26), 10803-10809CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        The prepn. of phosphorus-contg. trienes I featuring two diastereotopic vinyl moieties followed by a diastereoselective ring-closing metathesis is described. This methodol. allowed for the synthesis of novel highly functionalized P-stereogenic heterocycles II featuring both an exo- and an endocyclic double bond. An investigation into the factors influencing the diastereochem. outcome of the ring-closing metathesis is also presented, revealing that the geometry of the double bonds conjugated to phosphorus is important and that 1,3-stereoinduction is superior to 1,4-stereoinduction for these reactions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1CkurnI&md5=e95eb8b7871acb34498f361f6a609f1a

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        65a
        Two-fragment α-adrenolytics 3. Addition of primary amines to alkyl divinylphosphinates and phenyl(divinyl)phosphine oxide
        Reznik, V. S.; Levin, Ya. A.; Akamsin, V. D.; Galyametdinova, I. V.; Pyrkin, R. I.
        Russian Chemical Bulletin (Translation of Izvestiya Akademii Nauk, Seriya Khimicheskaya) (2000), 49 (3), 495-498CODEN: RCBUEY; ISSN:1066-5285. (Consultants Bureau)
        Primary alkylamines, β-aryloxyethylamines, or N-[β-(2-methoxyphenoxy)ethyl]-α,ω-diaminoalkanes react with alkyl divinylphosphinates or phenyl(divinyl)phosphine oxide to give the corresponding 4-alkoxy(4-phenyl)-1-alkyl-4-oxo-1,4-azaphosphorinanes. Reactions of the latter with mono- or dihaloalkanes afford 4-phosphapiperidinium halides. 1,4-Azaphosphorinanes contg. a β-aryloxyethyl fragment exhibit hypotensive activity.

      66. 66
        Bravo-Altamirano, K.; Huang, Z.; Montchamp, J.-L. Palladium-Catalyzed Phosphorus–Carbon Bond Formation: Cross-Coupling Reactions of Alkyl Phosphinates with Aryl, Heteroaryl, Alkenyl, Benzylic, and Allylic Halides and Triflates. Tetrahedron 2005, 61, 6315– 6329,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2005.03.107

        66
        Palladium-catalyzed phosphorus-carbon bond formation: cross-coupling reactions of alkyl phosphinates with aryl, heteroaryl, alkenyl, benzylic, and allylic halides and triflates
        Bravo-Altamirano, Karla; Huang, Zhihong; Montchamp, Jean-Luc
        Tetrahedron (2005), 61 (26), 6315-6329CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Direct formation of H-arylphosphinates and related compds. can be accomplished using palladium catalysis. This full paper examines the scope and some mechanistic aspects of this phosphorus-carbon bond forming reaction. The reactions of alkenyl and allylic halides are also described for the first time. This novel cross-coupling provides a convenient access to a variety of substituted H-phosphinates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXltFSgtrg%253D&md5=53d9d28cd71b2ad4390b0f69814007a5
      67. 67
        Kalek, M.; Jezowska, M.; Stawinski, J. Preparation of Arylphosphonates by Palladium(0)-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling in the Presence of Acetate Additives: Synthetic and Mechanistic Studies. Adv. Synth. Catal. 2009, 351, 3207– 3216,  DOI: 10.1002/adsc.200900590
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        67
        Preparation of Arylphosphonates by Palladium(0)-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling in the Presence of Acetate Additives: Synthetic and Mechanistic Studies
        Kalek, Marcin; Jezowska, Martina; Stawinski, Jacek
        Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2009), 351 (18), 3207-3216CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An efficient protocol for the synthesis of arylphosphonate diesters via a Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling of H-phosphonate diesters with aryl electrophiles, promoted by acetate ions, was developed. A significant shortening of the cross-coupling time in the presence of the added acetate ions was achieved for bidentate and monodentate supporting ligands, and for different aryl electrophiles (iodo, bromo and triflate derivs.). The reaction conditions were optimized in terms of amt. of the catalyst, supporting ligands, and source of the acetate ion used. Various arylphosphonates, including those of potential biol. significance, were synthesized using this newly developed protocol. Some mechanistic aspects of the studied reactions are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1Sjs77O&md5=6f586a1b6d26334a240916ef2e2c1b24

        68
        Microwave-assisted hydrolysis of phosphonate diesters: an efficient protocol for the preparation of phosphonic acids
        Jansa, Petr; Baszczynski, Ondrej; Prochazkova, Eliska; Dracinsky, Martin; Janeba, Zlatko
        Green Chemistry (2012), 14 (8), 2282-2288CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A new highly efficient method for the hydrolysis of acyclic nucleoside phosphonate diesters (or generally of any organophosphonates) to the corresponding phosphonic acids has been developed. This novel methodol. employs inexpensive hydrochloric acid in equimolar amts. to the no. of ester groups present in the mol. and thus, avoids using trimethylsilyl halogenides, the std. reagents for these types of transformations. Moreover, simple and easy work-up of the reaction mixt. affords very clean products in high yields (usually 77-93%). Another advantage of the described hydrolysis of phosphonate diesters is the fact that the course of the reaction can be instantly monitored through pressure changes in the reaction vessel. This green' method has also been successfully used for the prepn. of otherwise synthetically difficult to access (phosphonomethoxy)ethyl (PME) derivs. of guanine (PMEG) and hypoxanthine (PMEHx), and furthermore, the method gains access to important novel acyclic nucleoside phosphonates derived from 2-chlorohypoxanthine and from xanthine (e.g. PMEX).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVOmsrzF&md5=201d455ed1841f8ee3890b313b7b74f9
      69. 69
        Conibear, A. C.; Lobb, K. A.; Kaye, P. T. 31P NMR Kinetic Study of the Tandem Cleavage of Phosphonate Esters by Bromotrimethylsilane. Tetrahedron 2010, 66, 8446– 8449,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2010.08.058
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        69
        31P NMR kinetic study of the tandem cleavage of phosphonate esters by bromotrimethylsilane
        Conibear, Anne C.; Lobb, Kevin A.; Kaye, Perry T.
        Tetrahedron (2010), 66 (43), 8446-8449CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        1H and 31P NMR methods were used to access rate consts. and activation parameters for each of the consecutive 2nd-order silylation reactions involved in the overall transformation [RNHC(O)CH2P(O)(OEt)2 → RNHC(O)CH2P(O)(OEt)(OSiMe3) → RNHC(O)CH2P(O)(OSiMe3)2 (R = 4-acetyl-5-methylthiazol-2-yl)], while computational optimization of the rate consts. obtained from the initial, linear phase of each reaction has permitted an excellent fit with the exptl. data for the entire course of the reaction.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXht1Wlsb%252FP&md5=1436f012a34e478f960b4cc30aacc077
      70. 70
        (a) Holý, A. Simple Method for Cleavage of Phosphonic Acid Diesters to Monoesters. Synthesis 1998, 1998, 381– 385,  DOI: 10.1055/s-1998-2047
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        .

        For alternative approaches, see the folllowing, for example:

        (b) Golubski, Z. E.; Skrowaczewska, Z. New Synthesis of Cyclic Esters of Phosphonic and Thiophosphonic Acids. Synthesis 1979, 1979, 21– 23,  DOI: 10.1055/s-1979-28533
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      71. 71
        Yang, J.-C.; Gorenstein, D. G. Contribution of Ring Strain and the Stereoelectronic Effect to the Hydrolysis of Cyclic Five-Membered Ring Phosphorus Esters. Tetrahedron 1987, 43, 479– 486,  DOI: 10.1016/S0040-4020(01)89980-4
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        71
        Contribution of ring strain and the stereoelectronic effect to the hydrolysis of cyclic five-membered ring phosphorus esters
        Yang, Ji Charng; Gorenstein, David G.
        Tetrahedron (1987), 43 (3), 479-86CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020.
        The rate of base-catalyzed hydrolysis of cyclic five-membered ring 1,2-oxaphospholane I and 1,3,2-dioxaphospholane II and their acyclic analogs Et ethylphenylphosphinate (III) and di-Et phenylphosphonate (IV) were measured. The cyclic ester I hydrolyzes 6.2 × 103 times faster than III, corresponding to an activation free energy difference of 5.2 kcal/mol. This provides a good est. of the magnitude of ring strain in these cyclic esters. In contrast, cyclic ester II hydrolyzes 1.5 × 106 times faster than its acyclic analog IV, corresponding to an activation free energy difference of 8.4 kcal/mol. This latter energy difference is thought to be derived from both a ring strain effect (∼ 5.2 kcal/mol) and a stereoelectronic effect (∼ 3.2 kcal/mol).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXhtFamt7Y%253D&md5=0161cfc8dac6457635d9d84dfa527708
      72. 72
        Liu, Y.-F.; Wang, C.-L.; Bai, Y.-J.; Han, N.; Jiao, J.-P.; Qi, X.-L. A Facile Total Synthesis of Imatinib Base and Its Analogues. Org. Process Res. Dev. 2008, 12, 490– 495,  DOI: 10.1021/op700270n
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        72
        A Facile Total Synthesis of Imatinib Base and Its Analogues
        Liu, Yi-Feng; Wang, Cui-Ling; Bai, Ya-Jun; Han, Ning; Jiao, Jun-Ping; Qi, Xiao-Li
        Organic Process Research & Development (2008), 12 (3), 490-495CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
        Imatinib (I) and its analogs were successfully synthesized by an improved method in 19.5-46.2% total yield of six main steps. 2-Pyrimidinamines were prepd. by heterocyclization of (dimethylamino)propenone enaminones with guanidine nitrate without the use of a toxic cyanamide. N-(2-Methyl-5-nitrophenyl)pyrimidinamine key intermediates were prepd. by Cu-catalyzed arylation of 2-pyrimidinamines with 2-bromo-4-nitrotoluene. CuI was used instead of expensive Pd compds. in this C-N bond-forming reaction. Intermediate (pyrimidinylamino)nitrobenzenes were reduced by a N2H4·H2O/FeCl3 system using water as a solvent in good yields.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXks1Kmurc%253D&md5=e74be057c7147f44712c33c2adc0716e

        Google Scholar

      77. 77

        For primary carboxamide 30a and dimethylsulfonamide 31c no valid log D data could be determined at pH 11. As no ionization is expected at pH 2, the log D values measured at pH 2 are displayed instead in Figure 6.

      78. 78
        Haake, P.; Cook, R. D.; Hurst, G. H. Evaluation of the Basicity of Phosphine Oxides and Phosphine Sulfides by Measurements of Chemical Shift in Sulfuric Acid Solutions. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1967, 89, 2650– 2654,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00987a026
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        78
        Evaluation of the basicity of phosphine oxides and phosphine sulfides by measurements of chemical shift in sulfuric acid solutions
        Haake, Paul; Cook, Robert Douglas; Hurst, Gail H.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1967), 89 (11), 2650-3CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The pkBH+ values of Me2PO2H, Me3P(O)(OMe)2, Ph2P(O)Me, PhP(O)Me, Ph2P(S)Me, Ph(S)2, and Me2PS2H were detd. by measurements of chem. shift of Me groups bonded to Ph as a function of H2SO4 concn. The data indicate considerable π bonding in PS and PO bonds. Phosphine oxides are about 10-6 as basic as amine oxides, arsine oxides, and stibine oxides. Previous reports of the basicity of phosphine oxides are misleading. The method used here was validated by study of BzMe and AcNMe2; pK's of these compds. are known from other methods. 33 references.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2sXktFGgtro%253D&md5=6aac293bb8c1c184685f419963b89213

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        Remote modulation of amine basicity by a phenylsulfone and a phenylthio group

        ChemMedChem (2007), 2 (3), 285-287CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A series of Ph sulfones and phenylthioamines was studied with respect to their pKa values in water under std. conditions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXmtVWqtLk%253D&md5=1e5681e5549ca7fc205493c7db96262b

      81. 81
        Baldwin, R. A.; Cheng, M. T. Organometalloid Azides. IV. Preparation and Reactions of N,N’-[p-Arylenebis(diphenylphosphoranylidyne)]bis(P-phenylphosphonamidic Azides). J. Org. Chem. 1967, 32, 2636– 2639,  DOI: 10.1021/jo01283a066
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        81
        Organometalloid azides. IV. Preparation and reactions of N,N'-[p-arylenebis(diphenylphosphoranylidyne)]bis(P-phenyl phosphonamidic azides
        Baldwin, Roger A.; Cheng, Ming T.
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1967), 32 (8), 2636-9CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        cf. CA 67: 43881p. Phenylphosphonic diazide is treated with 1,4-C6H4(PPh2)2 and (p-Ph2PC6H4)2 to give compds. of the general formula [PhP(O)N3N:PPh2]2L (I) where L is p-phenylene or p,p'-biphenylylene. N,N'-Bis[p-phenylenebis(diphenylphosphoranylidyne)]bis-(P-phenylphosphonamide azide) and N,N'bis[p,p' - biphenylylenebis(diphenylphosphoranylidyne)]bis(P-phenylphosphonamide azide) are prepd. I are treated with Ph3P to give compds. of the general formula [Ph3P:NP(O)PhN:PPh2]2L; I are also hydrolyzed to give diacids of the general formula [PhP(O)OHNPPh2]2L.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2sXks1Cnu70%253D&md5=5aea2f6cbbea848b33bf466ad08a4d42
      82. 82
        Keglevich, G.; Grün, A.; Bölcskei, A.; Drahos, L.; Kraszni, M.; Balogh, G. T. Synthesis and Proton Dissociation Properties of Arylphosphonates: A Microwave-Assisted Catalytic Arbuzov Reaction with Aryl Bromides. Heteroat. Chem. 2012, 23, 574– 582,  DOI: 10.1002/hc.21053
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        82
        Synthesis and Proton Dissociation Properties of Arylphosphonates: A Microwave-Assisted Catalytic Arbuzov Reaction with Aryl Bromides
        Keglevich, Gyoergy; Gruen, Alajos; Boelcskei, Adrienn; Drahos, Laszlo; Kraszni, Marta; Balogh, Gyoergy T.
        Heteroatom Chemistry (2012), 23 (6), 574-582CODEN: HETCE8; ISSN:1042-7163. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        A series of substituted di-Et arylphosphonates was synthesized by the microwave-assisted Arbuzov reaction of tri-Et phosphite and aryl bromides in the presence of NiCl2 as the catalyst under solvent-free conditions in good yields. The resulting phosphonates were hydrolyzed to the corresponding arylphosphonic acids whose acidity was evaluated by physicochem. methods.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsFSntrrE&md5=8e35edb8782140c76b9a2fb5c8c8cbb7
      83. 83

        For the effects of ring strain on the hydrolysis of cyclic phosphonates see refs (71) and

        Dudev, T.; Lim, C. Ring Strain Energies from ab Initio Calculations. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1998, 120, 4450– 4458,  DOI: 10.1021/ja973895x
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        83
        Ring Strain Energies from ab Initio Calculations
        Dudev, Todor; Lim, Carmay
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1998), 120 (18), 4450-4458CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A new approach employing ab initio calcns. is suggested for evaluating the strain energy of ring mols. as well as for estg. the relative contribution of different sources of strain to the ring strain energy. The approach developed is calibrated by reproducing exptl. detd. strain energies of mono- and bicyclohydrocarbons, cyclic ethers, and amines. It is then used to predict ring strain energies of cyclic phosphoesters, hydrogen fluoride cyclic clusters, and magnesium dialdehyde cyclic chelates. The usefulness of the method is demonstrated in disclosing the role of ring strain in the enhanced reactivity of a five-membered cyclic phosphate relative to its acyclic analog and six-membered ring counterpart.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXis12qtr4%253D&md5=9718a8e40ac93879732469a604d9466d
      84. 84
        Manley, P. W.; Cowan-Jacob, S. W.; Buchdunger, E.; Fabbro, D.; Fendrich, G.; Furet, P.; Meyer, T.; Zimmermann, J. Imatinib: A Selective Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor. Eur. J. Cancer 2002, 38, S19– S27,  DOI: 10.1016/S0959-8049(02)80599-8
        [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      85. 85

        While imatinib (36) and the phosphorus-containing analogs 43–45 where tested as free base or free acid, the analogs 37–42 where employed as their TFA salts as obtained after purification by preparative reversed-phase HPLC. These salt form differences however do not affect the data obtained in assays starting from DMSO stock solutions using buffered conditions, such as the assay for log D, stability in human liver microsomes, or Caco-2 permeability. For solubility it does affect data from the shake-flask assay, but not data from the HPLC-based high-throughput assay. For a detailed comparison see Table S1 in the Supporting Information.

        There is no corresponding record for this reference.

        The properties of phosphinic and phosphonic acids in comparison to carboxylic acids will be reported in a separate account.

      87. 87
        Armarego, W. L. F.; Chai, C. L. L. Purification of Laboratory Chemicals, 5th ed.; Butterworth Heinemann: Oxford, U.K., 2003.
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      88. 88
        Harris, R. K.; Becker, E. D.; Cabral De Menezes, S. M.; Goodfellow, R.; Granger, P. NMR Nomenclature. Nuclear Spin Properties and Conventions for Chemical Shifts (IUPAC Recommendations 2001). Pure Appl. Chem. 2001, 73, 1795– 1818,  DOI: 10.1351/pac200173111795
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        88
        NMR nomenclature. Nuclear spin properties and conventions for chemical shifts (IUPAC recommendations 2001)
        Harris, Robin K.; Becker, Edwin D.; Cabral De Menezes, Sonia M.; Goodfellow, Robin; Granger, Pierre
        Pure and Applied Chemistry (2001), 73 (11), 1795-1818CODEN: PACHAS; ISSN:0033-4545. (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry)
        A review. A unified scale is recommended for reporting the NMR chem. shifts of all nuclei relative to the 1H resonance of tetramethylsilane (TMS). The unified scale is designed to provide a precise ratio, Ξ, of the resonance frequency of a given nuclide to that of the primary ref., the 1H resonance of TMS in dil. soln. (vol. fraction, φ < 1%) in CHCl3. Referencing procedures are discussed, including matters of practical application of the unified scale. Special attention is paid to recommended ref. samples, and values of Ξ for secondary refs. on the unified scale are listed, many of which are the results of new measurements. Some earlier recommendations relating to the reporting of chem. shifts are endorsed. The chem. shift, δ, is redefined to avoid previous ambiguities but to leave practical usage unchanged. Relations between the unified scale and recently published recommendations for referencing in aq. solns. (for specific use in biochem. work) are discussed, as well as the special effects of working in the solid state with magic-angle spinning. In all, nine new recommendations relating to chem. shifts are made. Standardized nuclear spin data are also presented in tabular form for the stable (and some unstable) isotopes of all elements with nonzero quantum nos. The information given includes quantum nos., isotopic abundances, magnetic moments, magnetogyric ratios and receptivities, together with quadrupole moments and line-width factors where appropriate.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XitVeltbw%253D&md5=678eae2d74c6c1e4321cd907a3d2129b
      89. 89
        Pandya, V.; Jain, M.; Chakrabarti, G.; Soni, H.; Parmar, B.; Chaugule, B.; Patel, J.; Jarag, T.; Joshi, J.; Joshi, N.; Rath, A.; Unadkat, V.; Sharma, B.; Ajani, H.; Kumar, J.; Sairam, K. V. V. M.; Patel, H.; Patel, P. Synthesis and Structure–Activity Relationship of Potent, Selective and Orally Active Anthranilamide-Based Factor Xa Inhibitors: Application of Weakly Basic Sulfoximine Group as Novel S4 Binding Element. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2012, 58, 136– 152,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2012.10.005
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        89
        Synthesis and structure-activity relationship of potent, selective and orally active anthranilamide-based factor Xa inhibitors: Application of weakly basic sulfoximine group as novel S4 binding element
        Pandya, Vrajesh; Jain, Mukul; Chakrabarti, Ganes; Soni, Hitesh; Parmar, Bhavesh; Chaugule, Balaji; Patel, Jigar; Jarag, Tushar; Joshi, Jignesh; Joshi, Nirav; Rath, Akshyaya; Unadkat, Vishal; Sharma, Bhavesh; Ajani, Haresh; Kumar, Jeevan; Sairam, Kalapatapu V. V. M.; Patel, Harilal; Patel, Pankaj
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 58 (), 136-152CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A novel series of potent and efficacious factor Xa inhibitors contg. a sulfoximine moiety as a novel S4 binding element in an anthranilamide chemotype has been identified. Lead optimization at this novel P4 group led to many potent factor Xa inhibitors with excellent anticoagulant activity in human plasma. Selected compds. were dosed orally in rats and checked for their ex vivo prothrombin time prolonging activity, which resulted in identification of compd. 5-chloro-N-(5-chloropyridin-2-yl)-2-(4-(N-(2-(diethylamino)acetyl)-S-methylsulfonimidoyl)benzamido)benzamide (I). The detailed pharmacokinetic evaluation and subsequent metab. study of I suggested the presence of an active metabolite. The compd. I and its active metabolite II demonstrated excellent in vivo efficacy in both arterial and venous thrombosis model in rats and were found to be highly selective against related serine proteases. Based on this promising profile, compd. I was selected for further evaluation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslOrsrrI&md5=cdc06710c5029dc63ba9ce427d367ea4
      90. 90
        Metcalf, C. A., III; Shakespeare, W. C.; Sawyer, T. K.; Wang, Y.; Bohacek, R. Novel Pyridopyrimidones and Uses Thereof. WO 2003/000270, 2003.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      91. 91
        Rogers, R. S. A General Synthesis of Phosphonic Acid Dichlorides Using Oxalyl Chloride and DMF Catalysis. Tetrahedron Lett. 1992, 33, 7473– 7474,  DOI: 10.1016/S0040-4039(00)60798-0
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        91
        A general synthesis of phosphonic acid dichlorides using oxalyl chloride and DMF catalysis
        Rogers, Roland S.
        Tetrahedron Letters (1992), 33 (49), 7473-4CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039.
        A general synthesis of phosphonic diacid dichlorides RP(O)Cl2 [R = cyclohexyl (C6H11), C6H11CH2, C6H11(CH2)4, CH2:CHCH2, Ph, PhCH:CHCH2] in 91-95% crude yield from RP(O)(OH)2 using oxalyl chloride and a catalytic amt. of DMF in CH2Cl2 is described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXht1CltLo%253D&md5=dd41aaae0edb3f4a712e084e7ad9e759
